source.raw_text:
The Goblet Squat Hold is a full-body exercise primarily targeting the quads, glutes, hamstrings, and core, with significant activation of the upper back, shoulders, and forearms for stabilization due to the front-loaded weight. The movement pattern is a bilateral squat, emphasizing an upright torso, deep hip flexion, and knee extension, making it excellent for learning proper squat mechanics while building strength and endurance in the entire posterior chain and stabilizing muscles. [1, 2, 3, 4, 5]  
This video provides a complete guide to the Goblet Squat: 
Muscles Worked 

• Primary Movers (Lower Body): Quadriceps, Glutes (Gluteus Maximus), Hamstrings, Adductors. 
• Stabilizers & Secondary Muscles: 

    • Core: Rectus Abdominis, Obliques, Erector Spinae (for upright posture). 
    • Upper Back: Traps, Rhomboids, Lats (to keep the weight close). 
    • Shoulders (Deltoids): Stabilize the weight. 
    • Forearms & Biceps: Grip and stabilization. 
    • Calves: Ankle stability. [1, 2, 3, 5, 6, 7]  

You can watch this video for a visual demonstration of the proper technique: 
Movement Pattern (The Squat Pattern) 

1. Starting Position: Feet shoulder-width apart, holding weight at chest. 
2. Descent: Initiate by pushing hips back, bending knees, maintaining an upright chest and core. 
3. Depth: Lower until thighs are near parallel or deeper, with knees tracking over toes. 
4. Hold (Isometric Phase): Maintain tension in the core and glutes, keeping the weight stable. 
5. Ascent (Concentric Phase): Drive through the heels, extending hips and knees to return to standing. [1, 3, 5, 8, 9, 10, 11]  

Key Benefits 

• Teaches Squat Form: The front load encourages a more upright torso, ideal for beginners. 
• Full-Body Integration: Excellent for building overall strength and endurance. 
• Core & Posture: Greatly improves core stability and spinal strength. [1, 3, 4, 5, 12]
